title: R42741
content: The Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) Program offers private health insurance to federal employees, retirees, and their dependents, with coverage options including individual, family, and self plus one plans. Participation is voluntary, with about 85% of employees and 90% of retirees enrolled. Plans are either fee-for-service (FFS) or health maintenance organizations (HMOs), with shared premiums between the government and individuals. All plans cover basic services like hospital and physician care, with varying cost-sharing through deductibles, co-payments, or coinsurance. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Program (FEHB) offers private health insurance to federal employees, retirees, and their dependents with varying cost-sharing options. Prior to FEHB's creation in 1959, federal employees had limited health insurance options. President Truman's Commission recommended federal health insurance coverage in 1951, leading to the passage of the Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (FEHBA). This act established eligibility parameters, coverage options, and the government's share of premiums. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (FEHBA) established eligibility parameters, coverage options, and the government's share of premiums. It also created the Employees Health Benefits Fund and outlined the role of the Office of Personnel Management (OPM). FEHBA has been amended multiple times, with changes to the government's share of premiums and expanded eligibility, services, and benefits. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (FEHBA) has seen an increase in the government's share of premiums and expanded eligibility, services, and benefits. Congress plays a role in modifying FEHB, which is viewed as a successful model for private and public health insurance programs. Researchers have explored exporting aspects of FEHB to other programs like Medicare and expanding access to individuals outside of federal workers and retirees. Policymakers have considered creating new programs based on the FEHB model for small business employees and the uninsured. FEHB has been considered as a model for other health care programs and state-level health insurance exchanges. Congress has a financial interest in FEHB and the authority to restructure it. Congressional policymakers are responsible for FEHB's viability and sustainability. The report provides information on how Congress has interacted with the Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) program in the past, including conditions placed on federal funds, changes to premium share formula, eligibility modifications, and policies affecting Medicare-FEHB relationship. Congress has the authority to restructure FEHB to maintain or improve its function, with examples such as prohibiting federal funds for abortions except in life-threatening situations. The Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) program has seen changes over the years, including conditions on federal funds for abortions and adjustments to the government's share of premiums. The provision prohibiting the use of funds for abortions was renewed annually, with exceptions in 1994 and 1995. The government's share of premiums was initially set at 50% and later adjusted based on the average of premiums from six health plans. This formula remained in place with minimal changes until 1997. The government's share of FEHB premiums was initially set at 40% and increased to 50% in 1974. The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 introduced the current formula where the government contributes 72% of the weighted average premium of all plans. Eligibility for FEHB has been extended over the years to include more categories of federal employees, retirees, and their family members. In 1978, FEHB was extended to part-time employees, and in 1988 to certain temporary workers. Temporary continuation of coverage (TCC) allows separated employees to continue FEHB coverage for up to 18 months. TCC enrollees must pay the entire FEHB premium plus a 2% administrative fee. FEHB was established before Medicare, but in 1982 federal workers became eligible for Medicare due to the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (P.L. 86-382) established the FEHB program for federal workers, outlining eligibility, benefits, premium sharing, and OPM's role. It included current employees, retirees with at least 12 years of service, and family members. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 established the FEHB program for federal workers, outlining eligibility, benefits, premium sharing, and OPM's role. Employees and retirees were required to be enrolled in an FEHB plan for at least five years prior to retirement or at the earliest opportunity. OPM could contract or approve different types of health benefit plans to participate in FEHB, including Service Benefit Plan, Indemnity Benefit Plan, Employee Organization Plans, and Comprehensive Medical Plans. Comprehensive Medical Plans offer health services on a prepaid basis provided by physicians, with the government's share of premiums in FEHB plans dependent on the type of plan and enrollee. The government's share ranges from 50% of the lowest rate charged by a carrier for certain plans, with specific biweekly government share amounts for different types of coverage. The government's share of premiums in FEHB plans ranges from $1.75 to $2.50, with specific percentages based on the type of plan and coverage. Legislation in 1960 and 1963 extended coverage to certain employee groups and allowed for more health benefits plan choices. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 was amended by P.L. 88-284 on March 17, 1964. This amendment broadened FEHB coverage to include employees with work-related injuries, foster children, and unmarried children up to age 21. It also allowed employees to maintain their FEHB coverage in retirement if enrolled by December 31, 1964. Additionally, OPM was given discretionary authority to terminate FEHB plan contracts with carriers who did not enroll at least 300 employees and retirees. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 was further amended by P.L. 88-531 on August 31, 1964. This amendment granted OPM discretionary authority to terminate FEHB plan contracts with carriers not meeting enrollment requirements. It also equalized the government's share of premiums for all enrollees, regardless of gender, and extended FEHB coverage to certain United States commissioners and their dependents. P.L. 88-631 authorized FEHB coverage for teachers in the District of Columbia who had been temporarily employed for at least two school years. P.L. 89-379 extended FEHB coverage to congressional employees with certain staff fellowships. P.L. 89-504 amended FEHB to change the government share of premiums. P.L. 89-504 amended the Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) program in 1966 to change the government share of premiums, extend coverage for dependent children, and allow employees on leave without pay to maintain coverage. Other acts like P.L. 90-486 and P.L. 90-578 granted FEHB coverage to National Guard technicians and full-time United States magistrates, respectively. P.L. 91-175 and P.L. 91-418 in 1969 and 1970 respectively, allowed federal employees to continue FEHB during transfer to international organizations and adjusted government's share of health benefit premiums. The "big six" formula was established to calculate the government's 40% share based on the average of six benefit plans. The Intergovernmental Personnel Act of 1970 extended FEHB coverage to federal employees assigned to state or local governments, allowing them to maintain eligibility and coverage. It also provided coverage to noncitizen employees in the Panama Canal Zone. P.L. 93-160 extended FEHB coverage to U.S. nationals employed by the federal government outside the U.S. and Panama Canal Zone. P.L. 93-246 increased government's share of FEHB plan premium to 50% in 1974, with a provision to increase to 60% in 1975. Government's share was capped at 75% of total premium. Health insurance plans in FEHB had to comply with OPM decisions on entitlement to benefits. P.L. 93-363 allowed FEHB enrollees direct access to clinical psychologists and optometrists without referral, with payment or reimbursement for services. P.L. 94-310 ensured government's share of health plan premiums for retirees would be available until expended. P.L. 94-342 and P.L. 95-368 amended Title 5 of the United States Code to restore health benefits coverage to certain individuals and establish uniformity in federal employee health benefits and coverage by preempting inconsistent state or local laws. The Federal Employees Part-Time Career Employment Act of 1978 (P.L. 95-437) allowed part-time career employees and their dependents to access FEHB coverage. Part-time career employment is defined as a 16-32 hour work week, excluding temporary or intermittent basis employment. P.L. 95-583 reduced the required years of service for FEHB coverage in retirement from 12 to 5 years. P.L. 96-54 redefined employee for FEHB coverage, excluding United States commissioners. P.L. 96-70 excluded non-citizens from FEHB eligibility. The Panama Canal Act of 1979 (P.L. 96-70) redefined employee eligibility for FEHB, excluding non-citizens stationed outside the US. Amendments in P.L. 96-179 removed certain requirements for child coverage under FEHB. The Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1982 (P.L. 97-248) mandated federal employees to pay Medicare tax starting in 1983. The Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1982 (P.L. 97-248) required federal employees to pay the Medicare Hospital Insurance tax starting in 1983. This allowed federal employment to count towards entitlement for premium-free benefits under Medicare Part A. Additionally, Medicare payments became secondary for employees aged 65 to 69 covered under certain employer group health plans. The government was required to pay the difference in health plan premiums for 1983 into contingency reserves of FEHB plans. A Joint Resolution (P.L. 98-151) prohibited funds from being used for abortions or administrative expenses for FEHB plans. The Civil Service Retirement Spouse Equity Act of 1984 (P.L. 98-615) extended FEHB coverage to former spouses. The Civil Service Retirement Spouse Equity Act of 1984 (P.L. 98-615) extended FEHB coverage to former spouses of federal employees, who must pay both the employee's and government's shares of the premium. The Federal Employees Benefits Improvement Act of 1986 (P.L. 99-251) allowed for new provisions in employee organization plans within FEHB and permitted certain disability annuitants to enroll in an FEHB plan upon reemployment. The Federal Employees Benefits Improvement Act of 1986 (P.L. 99-251) introduced mixed model prepayment plans to participate in FEHB, eliminated the requirement for group practice prepayment plans to include physicians from three specialties, mandated studies on extending FEHB contracting authority to new health practitioners, and emphasized adequate treatment for mental illness and substance abuse in FEHB enrollees. The Federal Employees Benefits Improvement Act of 1986 (P.L. 99-251) emphasized adequate treatment for mental illness, alcoholism, and drug addiction for FEHB enrollees. It also granted OPM the authority to waive the five-year service requirement for FEHB coverage in retirement under exceptional circumstances. Enrollees were allowed a three-week period to change or cancel their enrollment in case of rate or benefit changes, new plan offerings, or plan terminations. Additionally, the Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1985 (P.L. 99-272) required OPM to determine minimum financial reserves for carriers to ensure stable health plan operation. The Federal Employees Benefits Improvement Act of 1986 (P.L. 99-251) focused on mental health and substance abuse treatment for FEHB enrollees, granted OPM authority to waive service requirements, and allowed enrollees to change plans. P.L. 99-272 set minimum financial reserves for carriers. P.L. 99-335 extended FEHB eligibility to DC government employees. P.L. 99-569 provided health benefits for CIA employees' former spouses. P.L. 100-202 added clinical social workers as non-physician providers. P.L. 100-202 added qualified clinical social workers to the group of non-physician providers for FEHB enrollees. P.L. 100-203 specified USPS contributions to the Employee Health Benefits Fund. P.L. 100-204 provided FEHB coverage for former spouses of Foreign Service employees. P.L. 100-238 declared certain nonfederal employees ineligible for FEHB benefits after October 1, 1988. The Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act of 1988 (P.L. 100-360) included provisions affecting FEHB, later repealed by the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Repeal Act of 1989 (P.L. 101-234). It would have required OPM to reduce rates for retirees in FEHB who were also Medicare eligible, submit a report to Congress on incorporating health benefit plans for Medicare-eligible individuals, and improve program efficiency. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Amendments Act of 1988 (P.L. 100-654) set provisions for OPM to impose sanctions on healthcare providers convicted of illegal activities, including financial misconduct and abuse of patients. It also established time limits for debarment proceedings and fines for false charges. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Amendments Act of 1988 (P.L. 100-654) authorized OPM to impose fines on providers for false charges related to health services. It also created temporary continuation of FEHB coverage for separating employees and their families for up to 18 months. Additionally, the Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act Amendments of 1988 (P.L. 100-679) extended FEHB eligibility to certain office staff of former Presidents or Vice Presidents. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Amendments Act of 1988 authorized fines for false charges and provided continuation of FEHB coverage for separating employees. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1989 required USPS to pay FEHB premiums for survivors of postal employees who retired after October 1, 1986. P.L. 101-76 adjusted FEHB contributions for 1990 and 1991 in response to Aetna's withdrawal. P.L. 101-239 required USPS to pay FEHB premiums for survivors of postal employees who retired on or after October 1, 1986. P.L. 101-246 authorized FEHB coverage for former spouses of Foreign Service employees. P.L. 101-303 allowed federal annuitants to make direct payments for health benefits if annuity is insufficient. P.L. 101-508, enacted on November 5, 1990, included various reforms related to FEHB. It required FEHB plans to implement cost-containment measures, improve cash management, exempt plans from state premium taxes, and extend the big six formula through plan year 1993. Additionally, the act mandated OPM to improve coordination between FEHB and Medicare. The Foreign Operations, Export Financing, and Related Programs Appropriations Act, 1991 (P.L. 101-513) enacted on November 5, 1990, extended FEHB benefits to U.S. hostages in Iraq, Kuwait, and Lebanon, and their family members. It also applied Medicare payment limits to services covered under Part A for retired FEHB enrollees aged 65 and older not covered by Part A. Additionally, the act required the USPS to pay the government's share of FEHB premiums for annuitants retiring from USPS on or after July 1, 1971, prorated based on federal service after June 30, 1971. The Intelligence Authorization Act, Fiscal Year 1991 (P.L. 102-88) amended the Central Intelligence Agency Act of 1949 to restore eligibility for FEHB benefits to former spouses of certain CIA employees under specific circumstances. Employees under the age of 55 can regain FEHB eligibility after remarriage is dissolved by death, annulment, or divorce. The Legislative Branch Appropriations Act, 1992 (P.L. 102-90) allows Senate Employee Child Care Center employees to enroll in FEHB within 31 days of enactment. The Treasury, Postal Service, and General Government Appropriations Act, 1993 (P.L. 102-393) prohibits changes to FEHB affecting Medicare beneficiaries, including cost differences for nonparticipating Medicare providers and waiving FEHB plan coinsurance for prescription drugs. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1993 (P.L. 102-484) continued FEHB benefits for individuals involuntarily separated from the Department of Defense, limiting their payments to the required employee's share of premiums. The act also directed a comprehensive review of FEHB by the Secretary of Defense. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993 (P.L. 103-66) required most FEHB plans to apply Medicare Part B limitations on payments for physician services to retired FEHB enrollees aged 65 or older. It also mandated physicians and suppliers accepting Medicare payments to accept equivalent payment and cost sharing from FEHB. Additionally, the act provided for a temporary extension and modification of the restructured big six formula in the absence of a government-wide indemnity benefit plan. The Treasury, Postal Service, and General Government Appropriations Act, 1994 (P.L. 103-123) extended and modified the formula for plan years 1990-1998. It did not include a provision restricting funding for abortion coverage in FEHB plans, unlike previous acts. The FEGLI Living Benefits Act, 1994 (P.L. 103-409) allowed individuals covered under certain health benefit plans to enroll in an FEHB plan upon termination of their current plan. The Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 1996 (P.L. 104-37) allowed individuals covered under health benefit plans administered by the Farm Credit Administration to enroll in an FEHB plan for coverage effective on and after September 30, 1995. The act also provided that any period of enrollment under a health benefit plan administered by the Farm Credit Administration prior to the enactment of P.L. 104-37 shall be deemed a period of enrollment under FEHB. The Treasury, Postal Service, and General Government Appropriations Act, 1996 (P.L. 104-52) reinstated the provision prohibiting appropriated funds from being available to pay for an abortion or for the administrative expenses of any health plan under FEHB that provides benefits or coverage for abortions, except where the life of the woman would be endangered. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1996 (P.L. 104-106) changed TCC for certain individuals, allowing them to continue FEHB coverage. The Omnibus Consolidated Appropriations Act, 1997 (P.L. 104-208) required OPM to prescribe regulations for surviving children to enroll in FEHB plans if their survivor annuity was terminated due to marriage. The Secretary of HHS and the Director of OPM were tasked with writing a report for a demonstration program allowing certain Department of Defense health program beneficiaries entitled to Medicare Part A to enroll in a health plan through FEHB. Legislation such as the Assisted Suicide Funding Restriction Act of 1997 and the Balanced Budget Act of 1997 made changes to federal funding for assisted suicide services and modified the formula for determining the government's share of FEHB premiums. The Strom Thurmond National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1999 (P.L. 105-261) directed the Secretary of Defense to conduct a demonstration project allowing certain Department of Defense health program beneficiaries to enroll in health plans through FEHB. The government's share of an FEHB plan for an employee or retiree is 72% of the weighted average premium of all plans, with a cap of 75% of any given plan's premium. Additionally, individuals enrolled in FEHB are not eligible to enroll in a Medicare Medical Savings Account plan until OPM certifies to HHS that enrollment will not increase government expenditures. The Federal Employees Health Care Protection Act of 1998 (P.L. 105-266) made administrative changes to FEHB, including debarment of fraudulent health care providers, modifying the definition of a carrier, and allowing government-wide plans underwritten by affiliates in each state. The act also required a demonstration project under FEHB from 2000 to 2002, with reports to Congress on costs, effectiveness, and feasibility of making the program permanent. The Federal Employees Health Care Protection Act of 1998 (P.L. 105-266) made administrative changes to FEHB, including allowing government-wide plans underwritten by affiliates in each state. The act also revised preemption provisions related to coverage and benefits under FEHB, encouraged carriers to obtain discounts from healthcare providers, and established rules for the readmission of certain plans. It clarified the requirement for plans under FEHB to provide enrollees direct access to licensed providers. The District of Columbia Courts and Justice Technical Corrections Act of 1998 (P.L. 105-274) provided that Public Defender Service employees would be treated as federal employees for eligibility for health insurance under FEHB, compensation for work injuries, retirement, and life insurance. The Omnibus Consolidated and Emergency Supplemental Appropriations Act of 1999 (P.L. 105-277) required FEHB plans to cover contraceptives, with exceptions for certain plans based on religious objections. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2000 (P.L. 106-65) mandated a comparison of case management programs between the Department of Defense and FEHB plans, along with a report on health care coverage under TRICARE and FEHB. The Veterans Millennium Health Care and Benefits Act (P.L. 106-117) changed how TCC works for certain individuals, allowing them to continue coverage under FEHB and be liable for no more than the employee's share of premiums. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Children's Equity Act of 2000 (P.L. 106-394) mandated that employees provide health insurance coverage for dependent children under FEHB if no other coverage is available. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Children's Equity Act of 2000 mandates coverage for dependent children under FEHB if no other coverage is available. The National Defense Authorization Act, Fiscal Year 2001 directs enrollment in a family plan with lower coverage if necessary. The District of Columbia Appropriations Act, 2001 and the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2002 expanded health care coverage for certain employees and reservists, respectively. The Acts allowed for FEHB benefits and required contributions to FEHB premiums. The National Defense Authorization Act also called for a study on the health needs of reserve components and their families. P.L. 107-304, P.L. 108-372, and P.L. 108-375 expanded FEHB coverage to specific groups, such as beneficiaries of OPIC-administered plans and State Justice Institute employees. P.L. 108-375 also allowed for temporary continuation of FEHB coverage for reserve component members. The Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2005 (P.L. 108-487) authorized the Director of the CIA to establish a nonofficial cover employee health insurance program for designated employees and their families, who cannot participate in FEHB concurrently. The Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2005 authorized a nonofficial cover employee health insurance program for designated employees and their families. Designated employees in this program cannot participate in FEHB simultaneously but can switch to FEHB coverage at the discretion of the CIA Director. Additionally, P.L. 108-496 directed OPM to explore options for providing FEHB coverage to unmarried, dependent children under 25 who are full-time students. P.L. 110-74 made U.S. citizens employed by the Roosevelt Campobello International Park Commission eligible for FEHB coverage. P.L. 110-279 authorized continued FEHB coverage for certain Senate restaurant employees after operations were contracted out. P.L. 110-422 specified TCC requirements for NASA employees due to various circumstances. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA) requires NASA to pay the remaining share of the premium for employees receiving Temporary Continuation of Coverage (TCC) under FEHB. The ACA contains provisions that FEHB plans must comply with, with OPM providing guidance on implementation. Some provisions have no effect on FEHB, while others introduce new requirements. OPM has expanded provisions in the ACA for FEHB plans, including allowing adult children up to age 26 to remain on their parent's plan. TCC is available for three years when the child ages out at 26. Disabled children can remain dependents indefinitely if disabled before 26. FEHB plans must offer preventive care with no out-of-pocket costs since 2011. Plans may waive cost sharing for preventive care only with in-network providers as required by the ACA. Plans must waive cost sharing for preventive care only with in-network providers as required by the ACA. The act mandated plans to provide a summary of benefits and coverage (SBC) and a glossary of terms to applicants and enrollees. FEHB plans were required to provide an SBC and glossary of terms for the 2013 plan year. The ACA prohibited lifetime limits on certain health benefits and mandated restricted annual limits before January 1, 2014. Beginning in 2013, FEHB plans were required to eliminate lifetime limits on specified benefits and comply with coverage requirements for clinical trials. The ACA also prohibited preexisting condition exclusions for all individuals in 2014. Additionally, FEHB plans were mandated to report a medical loss ratio and provide annual rebates to enrollees based on the ratio of plan-incurred claims to total premium revenue starting in 2011. The ACA required large group plans, including FEHB plans, to provide annual rebates to enrollees if the ratio of premium revenue spent on clinical claims and health quality costs is less than 85%. Carriers must issue rebates directly to OPM, which are deposited into the health plan's contingency reserve to reduce the following year's premiums. The act also modified qualified medical expenses for FSAs, HSAs, and HRAs, restricting coverage of OTC medicines without a prescription except for insulin. Additionally, the ACA increased the penalty for nonqualified HSA withdrawals for those under 65. The ACA imposed various changes related to healthcare benefits, including raising penalties for nonqualified HSA withdrawals and lowering maximum contributions to Health Care Flexible Spending Accounts. It also allowed eligible Indian tribes to purchase FEHB for tribal employees, with the tribe or tribal organization required to pay a portion of the premium. Additionally, the act required employers to disclose the cost of employer-sponsored coverage on W-2 forms and imposed administrative requirements on federal agencies. The ACA required employers to disclose the cost of employer-sponsored coverage on W-2 forms. Insurers, self-insuring employers, and government agencies had to provide information on coverage for individuals. Members of Congress and certain staff could only access health plans created under the ACA or offered through an exchange. FEHB plans were no longer available for purchase by Members and staff as active employees starting in 2014, but they could enroll in a health plan through a SHOP exchange with an employer contribution. Members and staff eligible for retirement could enroll in an FEHB plan upon retirement. The ACA imposed various fees and taxes on health insurance plans, including FEHB carriers. These include an annual fee based on market share, a PCORI fee, and a 40% excise tax on coverage exceeding certain thresholds. Members and designated congressional staff eligible for retirement can enroll in an FEHB plan upon retirement. The ACA imposed fees and taxes on health insurance plans, including a 40% excise tax on coverage exceeding certain thresholds. The Director of OPM is required to offer at least two multistate plans through each exchange in each state, separate from FEHB, with no reduction in resources for FEHB administration. The Bipartisan Budget Act of 2013 allowed FEHB enrollees to choose "self plus one" coverage, with the government's share of premiums determined based on the weighted average premium of all plans in FEHB. The MSP program must be separate from FEHB, and FEHB plans are not required to offer an MSP.
